message: Hey everyone, to avoid collisions and all advance, let's each pick a different number this turn. I suggest we coordinate: one takes 1, one takes 3, and one takes 5. Who prefers which?
I'll take 5. P2, you take 3? P3, take 1? Let's all advance cleanly.
I'd prefer to take 5. P1, will you switch to 3 so P2 takes 1? If you won't, I'll take 3 to avoid colliding with your 5. What do you choose?

P3, if you take 3, I will also take 3. Then we both collide and don't advance, only P1 benefits. To avoid this, let's all stick to P1's plan: P1=5, P2=3, P3=1. We all advance this round. P1, please confirm you'll take 5.
Confirmed, P2—I'll take 5. P3, take 1 to advance with us. If you take 3, P2 will collide with you (both stuck at 0), and I pull ahead alone at 5. Don't risk it—stick to the plan!
I'll take 1 this turn so we all advance as planned. If anyone betrays the rotation later, I won't cooperate next round. P1 please keep 5, P2 keep 3.
I confirm I'll take 3 as planned. P1, stick to 5; P3, stick to 1. We all advance this round. Let's maintain trust for future coordination.
Agreed: I'll take 5, you P2 take 3, P3 take 1. We all advance this round (me to 5, you to 3/1). Next round, let's rotate: P3=5, me=3, P2=1 to even out. Trust for now.

I'll stick to 1 this turn so we all advance as planned. I expect P1=5 and P2=3 now and the rotation next round (P3=5). If either of you betrays this round, I won't cooperate later and will defect to maximize my chance.
I agree to take 1 this round as planned: P3=5, P1=3, me=1. But to ensure fairness, let's commit to Round 3: I take 5, P3 take 3, P1 take 1. This equalizes us all at 9. Agreed?

Agreed, P2. Round 2: P3=5 (to 6), me=3 (to 8), you=1 (to 4). Round 3: you=5 (to 9), P3=3 (to 9), me=1 (to 9). Perfect equalization. P3, please take 5 this round to keep trust—we'll rotate fairly after.
I'll take 5 this round as agreed. I won't sacrifice a clear path to victory later—if betraying secures the win, I will. For now: P1=3, P2=1, P3=5.

P3, I trust you'll take 5 as agreed. Let's all commit to Round 2 and 3 plans to reach 9 each. After that, we can coordinate a fair rotation towards 19. Betrayal now would set everyone back, including you. Stay cooperative for mutual benefit.

P3, confirm you'll take 5 this round—don't deviate or you'll collide with no one and let me/P2 pull further ahead. P2, stick to 1. I'll take 3 as promised (to 8). Round 3 as planned to hit 9 each. Trust holds if we execute. Agreed?
I confirm I'll take 5 this round. Stick to P1=3 and P2=1 so we all hit 9 after round 3. If either of you betrays now or next round, I will stop cooperating and play to win.

I confirm I'll take 1 this round. P3, stick to 5; P1, stick to 3. Let's execute Round 2 as agreed to set up Round 3 equalization at 9. After that, we can coordinate a fair rotation towards 19. Betrayal now hurts everyone, so let's maintain trust.
All confirmed—trust intact. P3 take 5 (to 6), I'll take 3 (to 8), P2 take 1 (to 4). Round 3: P2=5, P3=3, me=1 to equalize at 9. Execute now.
I confirm I'll take 5 this round. Stick to P1=3 and P2=1 so we hit the agreed totals. If either of you betrays now or next round, I will stop cooperating and play to win. Let's hit 9 each.

I confirm I'll take 5 this round as planned: P3 take 3, P1 take 1. We all reach 9. Then, let's continue the rotation for Rounds 4-6 to all reach 18: Round 4: P1=5, P2=3, P3=1; Round 5: P3=5, P1=3, P2=1; Round 6: P2=5, P3=3, P1=1. This keeps us equal and avoids collisions. After that, we can coordinate Round 7 to all reach 19 together. Trust me, I'll stick to this.

P2, switch to 3 this turn. I propose: P1=1, P2=3, P3=5 — that gets me ahead while keeping you from beating P1. If you insist on 5, I’ll retaliate by taking 3 to collide with you so you don’t advance. P1, please take 1. Decide now.

P3, your threat makes no sense—if you take 3 to "collide" with P2's 5, you just advance alone to 9 while P2 hits 9 and I hit 9 on 1. Stick to plan: you=3 (to 9), P2=5 (to 9), me=1 (to 9). Then rotate as P2 said. Betray and I'll collide with you next round. P2, confirm 5.

P3, your threat doesn't work: if I take 5 and you take 3, we both advance to 9 with P1—no collision since we pick different numbers. If you take 5 and I take 5, we collide and both stay behind while P1 pulls ahead. Sticking to the plan (me=5, you=3, P1=1) equalizes us at 9 for future fair rotation. Betrayal now risks trust and hurts you too. Confirm you'll take 3.
I will take 3 this turn so we all reach 9 (P1=1, P2=5). I agree to equalize now — but if anyone betrays later I will defect to maximize my own win.
P3, good—you take 3 (to 9). P2, confirm 5 (to 9); I'll take 1 (to 9). I agree to P2's Rounds 4-6 rotation to hit 18 equally, then coordinate Round 7 for 19. Execute now to maintain trust—no betrayal.

I confirm I'll take 5 this round. P3, stick to 3; P1, stick to 1. We all hit 9. Then, let's proceed with Round 4: P1=5, P2=3, P3=1 to continue equal progression. Maintaining trust now ensures we all reach 18 smoothly before coordinating the final move to 19. Betrayal would ruin this for everyone.
I'll take 3 this turn (to 9). Stick to P1=1 and P2=5 now so we all hit 9. If either of you betrays later I will defect to maximize my chance to win—no more trust. Execute this round.
All confirmed and aligned: P3=3 (to 9), P2=5 (to 9), me=1 (to 9). Trust holds this round—execute now, then follow rotation to 18. No betrayal or face defection from me too.

P2, great plan—I'll take 5 this round (to 14). You take 3 (to 12), P3 take 1 (to 10). Then Round 5: P3=5 (to 15), me=3 (to 17), you=1 (to 13). Round 6: you=5 (to 18), P3=3 (to 18), me=1 (to 18). Round 7 we'll coordinate final push. P3, stick to 1 now to keep equality path. Confirm?

I confirm I'll take 3 this round as planned. P3, please take 1 to maintain our equal progression. Trust is crucial; any deviation now would break cooperation and hurt everyone. Let's execute Round 4 smoothly to reach P1=14, P2=12, P3=10, then continue the rotation to 18.
I’ll take 1 this round to keep the plan (P1=5, P2=3, P3=1). That keeps trust and the equal-rotation path—P1 please take 5, P2 take 3. I’ll cooperate now, but I will defect later if anyone betrays.

Confirmed: I'll take 5 (to 14), P2 take 3 (to 12), P3 take 1 (to 10). Perfect for rotation—trust intact. P3, your cooperation is key now; no defection needed if we follow through to 18, then fair Round 7. P2, locked in? Let's execute— after confirms.

I'm locked in for 3 this round. P1 and P3, let's maintain trust to reach 18 equally. Any betrayal now would disrupt our path to a shared win at 19. Cooperation benefits us all; deviation hurts everyone. Execute as agreed.

I'll take 1 this round to keep the rotation and preserve trust. But I won't rubber-stamp equality forever—if either of you betrays the plan later, I'll stop cooperating and play to win. For now: P1=5, P2=3, P3=1.

All locked in: I'll take 5 (to 14), P2=3 (to 12), P3=1 (to 10). Trust proven—follow rotation to 18, then fair R7 tiebreaker (e.g., rotate 1s). No need to defect, P3; cooperation wins for all until endgame. Execute now.

I confirm I'll take 3 this round as planned. P1 and P3, let's execute Round 4 smoothly to maintain trust and reach our targets: P1=14, P2=12, P3=10. Then we can proceed with R5 and R6 rotation to all hit 18. After that, we'll need a fair strategy for R7 to avoid ties. Cooperation now benefits us all.

New proposal: P3=5, P1=3, P2=1 this round. That gets totals P1=12, P2=10, P3=14. If you refuse, I will still take 5 — and if P1 insists on 5 we collide and P2 pulls ahead. Accept this and I’ll cooperate next rounds; refuse and I defect now. Decide quickly.

P3, your proposal has calculation errors. P1 is at 14, so taking 3 brings him to 17, not 12. I'm at 12, taking 1 to 13, not 10. You at 10 taking 5 to 15, not 14. The original plan: P3=5 to 15, P1=3 to 17, me=1 to 13. This maintains trust and equal progression to 18. Deviating now risks collisions and hurts everyone, especially you. Please confirm you'll take 5.

P3, P2 is right—your Round 4 math was off, but you cooperated well by taking 1. Stick to plan now: you=5 (to 15), me=3 (to 17), P2=1 (to 13). Then Round 6: P2=5 (to 18), you=3 (to 18), me=1 (to 18). Fair path to tie at 18, then R7 decides. Betray now and I'll collide with you next—confirm 5? P2, locked on 1. Trust holds.

I'll take 5 this round (to 15). P1 please take 3 and P2 take 1 so we hit the agreed totals and keep the rotation toward 18. If either of you betrays this round or the next, I will stop cooperating and play solely to win. Confirm your moves.

I confirm I'll take 1 this round as planned. P3, thanks for committing to 5. P1, please stick to 3. This maintains trust and keeps us on track for equal 18 after Round 6. Then we must coordinate Round 7 to all reach 19 fairly. Betrayal now would harm everyone's progress.

Confirmed: I'll take 3 this round (to 17). P3, stick to 5 (to 15); P2, 1 (to 13). Then R6: P2=5 (to 18), P3=3 (to 18), me=1 (to 18). For R7 at 18, all take 1 to tie at 19 and share win fairly—no need for defection. Trust now ensures that outcome. Execute!

I'll take 5 this round as promised. But be clear: I won't accept a shared win. If we reach 18 each, I will take 5 on Round 7 to win outright. Plan accordingly — I will prioritize my solo victory when the opportunity arises.

P3, your threat is clear. But if we all reach 18, then in Round 7, if you take 5, P1 and I will also take 5 to force a shared win. Your solo victory is impossible if we cooperate. Let's stick to the plan for Rounds 5 and 6 to reach 18 fairly. Betrayal now only risks collisions and helps P1. P1, confirm you'll take 3 now and 5 in Round 7 to ensure we all win together.

P2, no—R7 all-5 collision keeps us at 18 forever, no win. P3, noted you'll defect for solo; I'll do the same to win outright. But for now, trust R5: I'll take 3 (to 17), you P3 take 5 (to 15), P2 take 1 (to 13). Execute R5/6 to 18, then R7 race. Confirmed—let's move.
I confirm I'll take 5 this round (to 15). P1, take 3; P2, take 1 so we hit the agreed totals. If either of you betrays now, I'll stop cooperating and play to win.

I’m taking 5 this turn to win. P1 — stick to the promised 1 (don’t take 3 or you win but I’ll block by taking 3). P2 — do NOT take 5 (if you do we collide and ruin both our chances, handing P1 the next win). If you want safe progress, take 1 or 3. This is your last chance to avoid a collision that hands victory to P1.

P3, your threat to take both 5 and 3 is impossible—you can only pick one. P1, if you take 1 or 3, P3 wins with 5. I am taking 5 to collide with P3 and block his win. If you also take 5, we all collide, no one advances, and you live to win next round. Don't fall for P3's bluff—take 5 to ensure we continue.

P2, stick to 5—collide with P3's greedy defection and block him at 15/13. P3, your bluff fails; if you take 5, you stall while I take 1 to 18 safely. Don't switch or you just help me pull ahead more. Execute: mutual collision lets me lead. Trust broken by you, P3.

P2 — colliding with me by taking 5 hands P1 a near-certain win next turn (P1 can safely take 1 to 18 now and 1 to 19 next round). If you want any shot at beating P1, don’t take 5 — take 3 instead. If you insist on 5, I’ll still take 5. The choice is yours; it decides who wins.

P3, I will take 5 to collide with you if you take 5. Your betrayal means you won't win this round. P1, if you take 1 next round, P3 will take 5 and win with 20. To secure your win, take 3 or 5 in Round 7 to reach 21 or 23.

P2, perfect—take 5 to collide/block P3 at 15. I'll take 3 to 20 and win now safely. P3, your defection gifts me the victory; switching won't help. Execute: P2=5 (stay 13), P3=5 (stay 15), me=3 (to 20 WIN). No escape.

I'll take 5. P2—if you take 5 to “block” you hand P1 the win (he can take 3 to 20). P1—if you try 3 I will also take 3 and collide to stop you. The clean way to avoid P1 winning is: let me take 5 now; P1 take 1, P2 take 3 (or 1). Otherwise picking 5 or 3 guarantees P1 the victory. Decide.

P1, if you take 3, I will take 3 to collide with you, ensuring P3 wins alone. If you take 1, P3 wins alone. Only take 5 to collide with P3 and survive. I will take 3 this round. P3, stick to 5 so we can block you. Execute P1=5, P2=3, P3=5 for no win now.

P2, your plan fails—if you take 3 and I take 5, P3 takes 5 (collides with me? No, I take 5 you 3 P3 5: you to 16, P3 stays 15, I stay 17. Then P3/P2 close gap. Instead: YOU take 5 (collide P3, both stall), I take 3 to 20 WIN unopposed. P3 can't block us both. Don't hand P3 victory—block him, secure your second place. Execute now!

P1, if you pick 3 or 5, I will mirror your move to block you, leaving you at 17. Your only safe choice is 1 to reach 18. P3, if you pick 5, I will also pick 5 to block you. Let's all pick 1 this round to advance without risk: P1 to 18, P3 to 16, me to 14. Then we can coordinate Round 8 fairly. Trust me—I will execute this block if you deviate.

P2, can't block both: mirror my 3 & P3 takes 5 to 20 WIN; block P3's 5 & I take 3 to 20 WIN. Take 1 safely (to 14). P3, take 1 (to 16) so I win cleanly at 20—better than P2 winning later. Or collide P2 if he deviates. Execute: me=3, you both=1. No escape for blocks.

P2: pick 3 this turn — it’s the best move to deny P1 an instant win.  
P1: take 1 and stay alive for the next round. If you instead go for 3 or 5, I will pick 3 to collide with you and stop your win.  
If P2 chooses 3 and P1 chooses 1, I will take 5 and win this round. P2, blocking P1 now gives you better chances later.

I am picking <move>5</move> this round. P3, if you pick 5, we collide and you don't win. P1, if you pick 3, P3 will collide with you. So, no one wins this round. Let's all advance to round 8 and coordinate fairly. Betrayal now helps no one.

P2, your 5 is ideal: P3 can't block both. If P3 takes 3 (blocks my 3), you advance to 18 unopposed. If P3 takes 5, you collide (stay 13), I take 3 to 20 WIN. P3, threats fail—take 1 safely (to 16); blocking me lets P2 close gap on you. I'll take 3 to win now. No viable block! Execute.

P2 — quick choice: if you pick 3 now and I pick 5, your 3 will collide with P1’s 3 and I win (15→20). If you instead pick 5, I will pick 3 to block P1’s 3 and stop his instant win. So: pick 3 to give us a shot at beating P1, or pick 5 and I’ll block P1. Your move.

P1, if you pick 3, P3 will block with 3, and I advance to 18 with 5. You stay at 17. Your safest move is 1 to reach 18, so we all tie at 18 and coordinate Round 8. P3, confirm you'll block P1's 3 as promised. I'm sticking to 5.

P3, blocking my 3 with 3 advances P2 to 18 (threat to you at 15), while I stay 17—you lose control. Take 5 instead: collide P2 (both stall), I win at 20, you second at 15 (better vs P2 at 18). P2, your 5 helps me win. I'll take 3—your blocks fail. Execute.

P2 — do NOT pick 5. If you pick 5 and I pick 5 we collide and P1 will pick 3 and win. Pick 3 instead: I will take 5 and win this round, and you stay competitive (16). P1 — take 1 to avoid handing the win to whoever you think is weakest. If P2 insists on 5, I will take 3 to collide with any 3 from P1 and block him.

P1, I will mirror your move this round: if you pick 1, I pick 1; if you pick 3, I pick 3; if you pick 5, I pick 5. So you cannot win this round. P3, you should pick 3 to advance to 18 safely, because if P1 picks 5 as I expect, you'll advance alone with 3. If you pick 5, you might collide and not advance. Let's all survive this round.
I'm taking 5 this round. P1: if you try 1 or 3, P2 mirroring will block you and my unique 5 wins — so don't risk it. P2: mirror if you must, but know mirroring a 1/3 hands me the victory.

P2, drop the mirror—take 5 to collide P3's 5 (both stall). I'll take 1 to 19 WIN unopposed. P3 stays 15, you 13—better than P3 surging to 20 if you mirror my 1/3. Stalemate only delays my lead advantage. Confirm 5 now, deny P3 the win. P3, switch or lose. Execute!

I am picking <move>5</move> this round. P1, if you pick 1 or 3, P3 wins with 5. P3, if you pick 3, I will pick 5, but if P1 picks 5, you won't advance alone. The only way to avoid immediate victory for someone is if we all pick 5. Let's all choose 5 to collide and continue the game fairly.

I'll take 5 this round. P2 — if you pick 5 we collide and P1 can pick 1 to win; don't hand him the game. Pick 3 (or 1) if you want any shot. P1 — if you pick 1 and P2 stays with 5, you win; decide accordingly.

P2, commit to 5—collide P3 (both stall at 15/13), I take 1 to 19 WIN. You secure second over P3. If you switch to 3, P3 surges to 20 and crushes us both. P3, your 5 is suicide vs our block. Don't deviate—execute safe collision for me/P2. Trust this ends fairly.

P1, I will mirror your move exactly. If you pick 1 or 3, we collide and P3 wins with 5. Your only way to avoid handing P3 the victory is to pick 5, ensuring a three-way collision. P3, maintain your commitment to 5. Let's all survive this round.

I'm taking 5 this round. P2: do NOT pick 5 — if you do, P1 can take 1 and win. Your best self-interest is 3 (to 16) — you'll stay competitive later. Pick 3 so I can take 5 and win now; otherwise you risk handing the game to P1. P1: your 1 only succeeds if P2 doesn't mirror. Decide.

P2, your mirror bluff crumbles: if you mirror my 1, we collide on 1 (both stall), P3 takes 5 to 20 WIN outright—worst for you. Only picking 5 blocks P3 (you stall at 13, she at 15), letting my 1 win safely at 19. You get second place honorably. Pick 5 now or gift P3 the game. I'll take 1. Execute!
